sections.title: Monitor and process ad-related events
sections.chapter: Working with the built-in capabilities of the SDK

tasks.title: Request to unload or hide ad

inlineContent.text: In this section, we’ll look at how an
can request an app to unload or hide the ad.
Let’s continue with
To monitor the moment when an ad wants to be removed or hidden, you can implement

. You may already remember its use with interstitial ads, where it is an essential part of the implementation. In the case of inline ads, this method can also be used in customised HTML or customised ads.
If you know that you do not have inline ads that can be hidden or removed, you can ignore this method for inline ads.

tasks.title: Monitor and process advertising tracking events

inlineContent.text: You may remember how we added the
modifier to the
has an
in it, which is why we added this modifier. Without it, this tracking will not work.
Let’s continue with
You can use two methods to monitor tracking events -
and
Let’s start with the first one, it signals a successful tracking on the server. As you can see, one tracking event can have multiple URLs to track on the server, so you have the
parameter, which contains a list of all the URLs that were requested.
The second method is called in case of an error. In this case, since the event can have several URLs, you get a list of those URLs that were successfully requested and those that failed.
In addition, you must specify how you want to handle this error with
. You can either
the error, in which case the server will not know about this event, or try to
the requests to the URLs that failed.
can perform tracking, depending on the response from the server. The SDK uses
to identify them. Most often, you’ll use these methods for debugging or handling errors related to tracking. In this section, we’ll look how we can work with
Let’s continue with
Same with tracking events, you can use two methods to monitor tap events -
and
Let’s start with the first one, it signals a successful tap processing. As you can see, all
except
should eventually show something to the user. In the case of
, the SDK only handles the tracking associated with the tap.
Read the
documentation to better understand when to use this event.
The second method is called in case of an error. In this case, we get the
that caused the
. Just like with
, you can decide how you will handle this error with
Most often, the error is related to an incorrect URL received in the advertisement, but in the case of
, it can be errors related to redirect processing.

tasks.title: Monitor and process advertising tap events

inlineContent.text: As a rule, tapping on an ad will trigger a

in the SDK. This can be either a simple opening of the URL to the user in an external browser or more complex logic with redirect processing. Most often, you’ll use these methods for debugging or handling tap-related errors. In this section, we’ll look how we can work with

The AdSDK offers extensive customisation functionality, such as creating customised ads and sending customised events. In this section, we will consider only those events that can occur when using a custom renderer or custom HTML advertising.
Let’s continue with
Let’s start with the simplest event, when the
wants to notify the application of an event with a name and an optional message –
The renderer can send any message that you can process. In our case, we just want to print this event.
In addition, the custom
can perform custom tracking. To monitor such events, you can use
and
The logic is similar to tracking or tap events monitoring and handling. You can get the name of the event, the URL where the request was made, a possible error, and decide how to handle it.

abstract.text: This tutorial will guide you how to create and display inline ads. An inline ad is an ad created to be displayed in your view hierarchy.
